content.p: We took a random sample from the 2000 U.S. Census. Here is part of the dataset:

body.p: Who are the individuals described by this data?

multiple_choice.choice: People living in the United States in the year 2000
People with families in the year 2000

response.feedback: Correct. The U.S. Census is completed by people living in the United States.
Incorrect. People with families are a subset of this sample, but the individuals represent a larger group.

part.hint: Individuals are the people or objects described by the data.

body.p: What type of variable is zipcode?

response.feedback: Correct. Zipcode is a categorical variable because it categorizes individuals by geographic location.
Incorrect. A quantitative variable has numerical values that can be averaged. A zip code is a number, but it does not make sense to average zip codes.

part.hint: A categorical variable puts individuals into categories. A quantitative variable is a numerical measurement that can be averaged.

body.p: What type of variable is Family_Size?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Family_Size is a variable with numerical values that can be averaged. Since Family_Size is a count rather than a grouping (0–2 kids, 3–4 kids, more than 4 kids), it is quantitative.
Correct. Family_Size is a variable with numerical values that can be averaged.

part.hint: A categorical variable puts individuals into categories. A quantitative variable is a numerical measurement that can be averaged.

body.p: What type of variable is Annual_income?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Annual_income is a variable with numerical values that can be averaged. Since Annual_income is reported as numerical values rather than a grouping (less than $1,000, $1000–$10,000, $10,001–$20,000, more than $20,000), it is quantitative.
Correct. Annual_income is a variable with numerical values that can be averaged.

part.hint: A categorical variable puts individuals into categories. A quantitative variable is a numerical measurement that can be averaged.
